abstracts.cdata!:
The report concludes that on balance the
            project's outcome was satisfactory, and project
            sustainability was rated as likely. Overall, the World
            Bank's performance can be considered satisfactory. The
            main shortcoming was the conflicting signals given to the
            Borrower by the Bank's transport sector staff in charge
            of the project, on one side, and the Bank's
            macroeconomic staff and the IMF on the other. In this sense,
            the Bank must share responsibility for the unsatisfactory
            performance of the Government. (Notwithstanding this
            finding, the report finds on balance that Borrower
            performance can be considered satisfactory.) On the other
            hand, high marks are due to the Bank for untiring and
            patient sector dialogue and intellectual leadership to
            improve sector performance with Government authorities at
            the macro and sector levels. Lessons learned include the
            following: In order to reduce dependence on expatriate
            technical assistance personnel, the project supported the
            strengthening of local staff capacity, and the technical
            assistance provided undet the project was focused
            accordingly. However, the role of technical assistance and
            responsibility-taking is changing, and the methods and tools
            they provide have to be continuously assimilated and applied
            to achieve performance results. There is a need for
            continued close coordination and within the Bank and between
            the Bank and the IMF. Road funds need to be independent and
            at arms length from the Government.
